revision.text:
[[File:Buttered cat.png|thumb|A cartoon illustration of the [[thought experiment]]]]
The '''buttered cat paradox''' is a common joke based on the [[tongue-in-cheek]] combination of two [[adage]]s:
* [[Cat righting reflex|Cats always land on their feet]]. * Buttered toast always lands [[Buttered toast phenomenon|buttered side down]].
The [[paradox]] arises when one considers what would happen if one attached a piece of buttered toast (butter side up) to the back of a cat, then dropped the cat from a large height. The buttered cat paradox, submitted by artist [[John Frazee]] of [[Kingston, New York]], won a 1993 ''[[Omni (magazine)|OMNI]]'' magazine competition about paradoxes.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Morris |first=Scot |date=July 1993 |title=I have a theory... |magazine=Omni |url=http://www.housevampyr.com/training/library/books/omni/OMNI_1993_07.pdf |page=96 |volume=15 |issue=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Verley |first=Jason C. |date=November 2001 |title=Letters: More on Alternate Theories |magazine=APS News |publisher=[[American Physical Society]] |url=http://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/200111/letters.cfm |volume=10 |issue=10}}</ref> The basic premise, stating the conditions of the cat and bread and posed as a question, was presented in a routine by comic and juggler [[Michael Davis (juggler)|Michael Davis]], appearing on ''[[The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson]]'', July 22, 1988.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uq0YjR11bx8 ''The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson'', July 22, 1988]</ref>
== Thought experiments == Some people jokingly maintain that the experiment will produce an [[anti-gravity]] effect. They propose that as the cat falls towards the ground, it will slow down and start to rotate, eventually reaching a [[steady state]] of hovering a short distance from the ground while rotating at high speed as both the buttered side of the toast and the cat’s feet attempt to land on the ground.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waikato.ac.nz/fmd/newsletter/Newsletter_No14.pdf |title=UoWaikato newsletter |format=PDF |date=August 2003 |publisher=University of Waikato |accessdate=2012-06-20 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref> In June 2003, Kimberly Miner won a [[Student Academy Award]] for her film ''Perpetual Motion''.<ref>Available at http://www.kminer.net/2011/07/perpetual-motion/ {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202085129/http://www.kminer.net/2011/07/perpetual-motion/# |date=2015-02-02 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scifidimensions.com/Apr04/oscaranimation.htm |title=Oscar Nominated Animated Shorts 2003 |publisher=Scifidimensions.com |date=2004 |first=John C. |last=Snider |accessdate=2012-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204063041/http://www.scifidimensions.com/Apr04/oscaranimation.htm |archivedate=2012-02-04 |df= }}</ref> Miner based her film on a paper written by a high-school friend that explored the potential implications of the cat and buttered toast idea.<ref>{{cite web |first=PG |last=Klein |website=[[University of Leeds]], School of Physics & Astronomy |url=http://www.physics.leeds.ac.uk/pages/PerpetualMotion |title=Perpetual Motion |date=2002-12-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022204806/http://www.physics.leeds.ac.uk/pages/PerpetualMotion |archivedate=2008-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rit.edu/success.php?s=43 |title=Student wins Academy Award for animated film |website=[[Rochester Institute of Technology]] |date=Spring 2004 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
== In humor == The faux paradox has captured the imagination of science-oriented [[humorist]]s. In May 1992, the [[Internet Oracle|Usenet Oracle]] Digest #441 included a question from a supplicant asking about the paradox.<ref name=oracle>{{cite web |work=[[Internet Oracle|Usenet Oracle]] |url=http://internetoracle.org/digest.cgi?N=441#441-07 |title=Usenet Oracularities #441 |date=1992-05-04 |editor-first1=Steve |editor-last=Kinzler |editor-link=Steve Kinzler |author=Usenet Oracle}}</ref> Testing the theory is the main theme in an episode of the [[comic book]] strip ''[[Jack B. Quick]]'', the title character seeks to test this theory, leading to the cat hovering above the ground, with the cat's wagging tail providing propulsion. The March 31, 2005, strip of the [[webcomic]] ''[[Bunny (webcomic)|Bunny]]'' also explored the idea in the guise of a plan for a "Perpetual Motion MoggieToast 5k Power Generator", based on [[Sod's law]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bunny-comic.com/211.html |title=Feline cunning and sods law |work=[[Bunny (webcomic)]] |first=Huw "Lem" |last=Davies |number=211 |date=2005-03-31 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> In ''Science Askew'', Donald E. Simanek comments on this phenomenon.<ref name="SimanekHolden2002">{{cite book |last1=Simanek |first1=Donald E. |last2=Holden |first2=John C. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Science Askew: A Light-hearted Look at the Scientific World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ldX0FkgurzoC&pg=PA201 |accessdate=2010-06-30 |year=2002 |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=978-0-7503-0714-7 |page=201}}</ref>
The idea appeared on the British [[panel game]] ''[[QI]]'', where the idea was discussed. As well as talking about the idea, they also brought up other questions regarding the paradox. These included: *"Would it still work if you used [[margarine]]?", *"Would it still work if you used [[I Can't Believe It's Not Butter]]?", and *"What if the toast was covered in something that was not butter, but the cat thought it was butter?" (the idea being that it would act like a [[placebo]]).<ref name="QI">{{cite episode |title=Hypothetical |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/qi/episodes/8/8/ |series=QI |serieslink=QI |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |location=London |airdate=2010-11-05 |seriesno=H |number=8 |first1=Sandi |last1=Toksvig |first2=Johnny |last2=Vegas |first3=John |last3=Lloyd |last-author-amp=yes}}</ref>
The paradox also appeared in the episode "Gravitational Anarchy" of the scientific podcast ''[[Radiolab]]''.<ref name="Radiolab">{{cite episode |url=http://www.radiolab.org/story/102525-vertigo/ |title=Gravitational Anarchy |series=[[Radiolab]] |network=[[NPR]] |time=20:48 |date=2010-11-29 |accessdate=2015-01-11 |first1=Robert |last1=Krulwich |authorlink1=Robert Krulwich |first2=Jad |last2=Abumrad |authorlink2=Jad Abumrad |first3=David (guest) |last3=Quammen |authorlink3=David Quammen |first4=Neil (guest) |last4=deGrasse Tyson |authorlink4=Neil deGrasse Tyson |last-author-amp=yes}} [https://itunes.apple.com/podcast/wnycs-radiolab/id152249110 Alternate link] via [[iTunes]].</ref> Later, a humoristic explainer animation<ref name="The Cat and Jelly Toast Experiment">{{cite web |author=[http://www.barqvideo.com barqvideo] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y7Is22CmY_Y |title=The Cat and Jelly Toast Experiment aka the Buttered Cat Paradox explainer |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2012-04-25 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> was put together by the animated production company Barq, based on an extracted audio clip from the ''Radiolab'' episode.
Brazilian [[energy drink]] brand [[Flying Horse (energy drink)|Flying Horse]] has released an award-winning commercial<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adforum.com/award/showcase/6653604/2012/ad/34474939 |title=2012 Young Director Award CFP-Europe |website=[[AdForum]] |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=<!--undated-->}}</ref> that simulates the recreation of this phenomenon, which is then used to create [[perpetual motion|perpetual energy]].<ref>{{cite web |author=vibeFlyingHorse |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8yW5cyXXRc |title=Flying Horse - Gatorrada (Cat-Toast) |publisher=YouTube |date=2012-04-10 |accessdate=2014-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/energy-drink-makes-most-buttered-cat-paradox-140523 |title=Energy Drink Makes the Most of the Buttered-Cat Paradox Age-old physics law inspires Ogilvy ad |first=Gabriel |last=Beltrone |date=2012-05-14 |work=[[Adweek]]}}</ref>
It also appeared in a comics series called ''[[Kid Paddle]]'' where Kid tells the story to his gullible friend Horace while at the dinner table. The comic is fairly popular in France and Belgium.
== In reality == In reality, cats possess the ability to turn themselves right side up in mid-air if they should fall upside-down, known as the [[cat righting reflex]]. This enables them to land on their feet if dropped from sufficient height, about {{Convert|30|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://helix.gatech.edu/Classes/ME3760/1998Q3/Projects/Nguyen/ |title=How does a Cat always land on its feet? |first=Huy D. |last=Nguyen |date=1998 |publisher=Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Medical Engineering |accessdate=2014-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010410235503/http://helix.gatech.edu/Classes/ME3760/1998Q3/Projects/Nguyen/ |archivedate=2001-04-10 |df= }}</ref>
Toast, being an inanimate object, lacks both the ability and the desire to right itself. A study at [[Manchester Metropolitan University]] involving dropping 100 slices under laboratory conditions established that toast typically lands on the floor butter-side-down as a result of the manner in which it is typically dropped from a table, and the aerodynamic drag caused by the air pockets within the bread. The toast is typically butter-side-up when dropped. As it falls, it rotates; given the typical speed of rotation and the typical height of a table, a slice of toast that began butter-side-up on the table will land butter-side-down on the floor in 81% of cases.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/-rav--r-manchester-boffins-5842879 |title=(-Rav)/ t = R: Manchester boffins find formula for why toast lands butter side down |first=Chris |last=Slater|newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-09-05 |accessdate=2017-03-06 }}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Logic}} * [[Irresistible force paradox]] * [[List of paradoxes]] * [[Schrödinger's cat]] * [[Perpetual motion]] * [[High-rise syndrome]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.frazeefinearts.com Frazee Fine Arts] Website of Teresa and John Frazee. * {{cite journal|date=16 November 1996|title=Feedback|magazine=[[New Scientist]]|issue=2056|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg15220568.300}} * [http://www.xs4all.nl/~jcdverha/scijokes/2_21.html#subindex Loopholes for the paradox]

{{Infobox organization |name = Cauliflower Alley Club |image = CAC logo.jpg |image_border = |size = |caption = CAC logo |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = 1965 |extinction = |type = [[Professional wrestling]] |headquarters = 4138 187th Ave SE [[Issaquah, Washington]], United States |location = |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Brian Blair]] |key_people = '''EXECUTIVE BOARD OF DIRECTORS:'''

Bruce Tharpe (Legal Counsel) |budget = |website = http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/ }} The '''Cauliflower Alley Club''' is a non-profit [[fraternal organization]], which includes a newsletter and website, comprising both retired and active [[professional wrestler]]s and boxers in North America. Established in 1965 by [[Mike Mazurki]] and [[Art Abrams]], the organization hosts an annual reunion dinner which has traditionally been attended by celebrities and other professional athletes. Several historical [[Hollywood]] locations have been home to the reunion banquets such as the Masquer's Club, the [[Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel|Roosevelt Hotel]] and the [[Old Spaghetti Factory]] as well as [[Riviera (hotel and casino)|The Riviera]] and the {{RMS|Queen Mary}}. == History == The Cauliflower Alley Club was founded in 1965 by [[Mike Mazurki]] as a [[fraternal organization]] of professional wrestlers, boxers, and actors.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2010/04/20/13651866.html|title=Unpredictability rules at Cauliflower Alley Club|date=April 20, 2010|last=Oliver|first=Greg|accessdate=May 4, 2018|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}}{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2015/04/04/22326971.html|title=Cauliflower Alley Club set for a big 50th bash|date=April 4, 2015|last=Smith|first=Caleb|accessdate=May 4, 2018|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} The first annual reunion dinner was held at the Baron's Castle Buffet Restaurant in [[Los Angeles, California]]. The Club also presents numerous awards annually at the reunion dinner. Several prominent former profesional wrestlers have been president of the club, including [[Red Bastien]], [[Nick Bockwinkel]], and the current president [[Brian Blair]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2007/04/22/4103026.html|title=That's entertainment! CAC banquet ranges from songs to stories to spoofs|date=April 22, 2007|last=Johnson|first=Steven|accessdate=May 4, 2018|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} The Club has a "Benevolent Fund to help people involved in professional wrestling in times of difficulty. Proceeds are raised for the fund during the annual reunion weekend. ==Awards== ===2019=== *'''Iron Mike Mazurki Award''': [[Mark Henry]]https://twitter.com/CACReunion/status/1063439165101146113 ===2018=== *'''Iron Mike Mazurki Award''': [[Baron von Raschke]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/baron-von-raschke-to-be-honored-this-year/|title=Baron von Raschke to be Honored This Year {{!}} Cauliflower Alley Club|website=www.caulifloweralleyclub.org|access-date=2018-01-18}} *'''Men's Wrestling Award:''' [[Tony Storm]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/tony-storm-to-be-honored-in-2018/|title=Tony Storm To Be Honored in 2018 {{!}} Cauliflower Alley Club|website=www.caulifloweralleyclub.org|access-date=2018-01-18}} *'''Men's Wrestling Award:''' [[Greg Valentine]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/greg-valentine-to-receive-a-2018-mens-wrestling-award/|title=Greg Valentine To Receive a 2018 Men’s Wrestling Award {{!}} Cauliflower Alley [[1080i]] [[HDTV]] | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{start date|2014|03|24}} | last_aired = {{end date|2016|07|24}} | website = http://www.hotstar.com/#!/chokher-tara-tui-631-s | website_title = Official Website }} '''Chokher Tara Tui''' ({{lang-bn|চোখের তারা তুই}}) is a recent Popular Kolkata-Bengali TV series from [[STAR Jalsha]]. The TV series starred [[Joy Kumar Mukherjee]] & [[Ritabhari Chakraborty]] as the two protagonists of the serial, Ritabhari who had earlier acted on another STAR Jalsha TV series ''Ogo Bodhu Sundari''. The series was aired for the first time on STAR Jalsha on 24 March 2014 at 7:30 PM (IST). This serial stars Ipsita Mukherjee (formerly Ritabhari Chakraborty) as Tutul Das Gupta, who is one of the greatest fans of the famous actor Ayush Kumar Chatterjee (Joy Mukherjee), of how she fulfills or achieve her dreams and love for Ayush.{{Cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bengali/movies/news/joy-kumar-mukherjee-is-a-gym-freak/articleshow/59861111.cms|title=Joy Kumar Mukherjee is a gym freak|website=TIMESOFINDIA.COM|language=en-US|date=Aug 1, 2017}} {{Cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/are-senior-bengali-film-actors-a-neglected-lot/story-bEF12q9Xuk0FkpKRsJsbHP.html|title=Are senior Bengali film actors a neglected lot?|website=.hindustantimes|language=en-US|date=Nov 11, 2016 }} ==Plot== The series starts with a rehearsal for a function where an eminent celebrity, Ayush Kumar (Joy Mukherjee), is said to visit. Tutul (Ipsita Mukherjee), a tremendous fan of Ayush, kisses and counts the number of poster of the newly released movie which stars Ayush. She and her friends play [[Holi]] and get late to the rehearsal where she was supposed to be the lead dancer. The main theme of the story is quite similar to [[Om Shanti Om]] and [[Guddi (1971 film)|Guddi]], where there is a crazy fan that goes to great lengths to be with the person of their dreams. This serial is based on the life of Tutul and her remarkable journey to achieve her dreams. Tutul is a simple girl from the small town of Madhupura. Orphaned at a young age, Tutul has been brought up by her extended family. She is sprightly and vivacious and lives life to the fullest. She is madly in love with Ayush, the celebrated movie star. Tutul’s only aim in life is to be with Ayush and have him in her life. And like love sees no reason Tutul too defies all reasons to start out on an extraordinary journey to fulfill this dream of hers. Her journey is packed by entertaining plot twists like those in the movies and is sure to offer an emotional roller coaster ride. The serial came to an end on 24 July 2016 after 793 episodes. ==Cast== ===Main Cast=== *[[Joy Kumar Mukherjee|Joy]] as Ayush Kumar Chatterjee *[[Ritabhari Chakraborty]] / Ipshita Mukherjee as Sohaag Chatterjee / Tutul *Debottam Majumder as Rishi Banerjee ===Recurring Cast=== *[[Kamalika Banerjee]] / [[Bidipta Chakraborty]] as Jaya Chatterjee / Payel *[[Shankar Chakraborty]] as Dipoman Chatterjee / Deep *[[Debshankar Haldar]] as Debraj Dasgupta *[[Aparajita Adhya]] as Aparupa *[[Abhishek Chatterjee]] as Yuboraj *[[Madhabi Mukherjee]] as Uma Chatterjee *Sudipta Banerjee as Madhushree *Papiya Adhikari as Lekha Banerjee *[[Sabitri Chatterjee]] as Sabitri Devi *[[Pijush Ganguly]] as Angshuman Chatterjee *Anusuya Majumder as Umrao Jaan *Suchishmita Chowdhury as Kuheli Chatterjee *Oishi Bhattacharya as Tua *[[Samata Das]] as Mitul *Milan Roy Chowdhury as Anirban Dasgupta / Bappa *Tanuka Bhattacharya as Tutul’s Aunt *Surojit Bandopadhyay as Chandrashekhar/Shekhar *Soma Chakraborty as Rajlakshmi / Lakshmi *Sudip Sengupta as Rangan *Papiya Sen as Tutul's Grandmother ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[[Gachkouto]] *[[Keya Patar Nouko]] *[[Magic Moments Motion Pictures]] *[[List of programs broadcast by Star Jalsha]] ==External links== * [http://www.hotstar.com/#!/chokher-tara-tui-631-s Official Website] on [[hotstar]] * {{facebook|id=Chokher-Tara-Tui-Star-Jalsha/591300087628397|name=Chokher Tara Tui - Star Jalsha}} * {{YouTube|id=0QnybVYQ2Lg|title=Chokher Tara Tui}} * [http://sholoanabangaliana.in/blog/2014/03/20/star-jalsha-serial-chokher-tara-tui-story-traces-the-journey-of-a-fan-to-meet-her-superstar-and-be-a-part-of-his-life/ Sholoana Bangaliana] {{Magic Moments Motion Pictures}} [[Category:2014 Indian television series debuts]] [[Category:Bengali-language television programming in India]] [[Category:Soap operas]] [[Category:Bengali television serials]]

The '''Chubu Walkathon and International Charity Festival''' is a foreign organized charity event started in 1991 in [[Nagoya, Japan]] by members of the now defunct American Business Community Nagoya (ABCN); in November 2000 the ABCN merged with and became the [[Chūbu region]] chapter of the [[American Chamber of Commerce Japan (ACCJ)]].
The event was originally called the ''Nagoya Walkathon''.<ref>[http://en.chubuwalkathon.com/history History | Chubu Walkathon<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Held annually on a Sunday in May this event is sponsored by the [[American Chamber of Commerce Japan (ACCJ)|American Chamber of Commerce in Japan (ACCJ)]] and [http://www.nagoyais.jp/nis/index.html Nagoya International School (NIS)]. Its main purpose is to join the international community with Japanese friends and companies in raising money for local orphanages and charities.
== Attendance and donation totals == * In 2013 the event was attended by 3500 people who raised a total of 7.7 million yen - 7 million yen for orphanages and local charities and an additional 700,000 Yen for people affected by the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami. * In 2012 the event was attended by 3600 people who raised a total of 9 million yen - 8 million yen for orphanages and local charities and an additional 1 million Yen for people affected by the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. The mayor of Nagoya [[Takashi Kawamura (politician)|Takashi Kawamura]] participated.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://nagoyawalkathon.com/en/ Nagoya Walkathon Website]</ref> * In 2011 the event was attended by 3500 people who raised a total of 12.7 million yen - 7.7 million yen for orphanages and local charities and an additional 5 million Yen for people affected by the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> * Attendance in 2010 was over 2000 people, and the event raised 6 million yen for orphanages and local charities.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> * Attendance in 2009 was up to 2500 people, and the event raised 8 million yen for orphanages and local charities. Nagoya Mayor Takashi Kawamura participated.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
== Venues == * 2013 - [http://www.aichi-toshi.or.jp/park/park%28HP%29/morikoro/index.html Moricoro Park] * 2012 - Moricoro Park * 2011 - Moricoro Park * 2010 - [[Tsuruma Park]] * 2009 - Tsuruma Park * 2008 - [[Meijō Park]] * 2007 - Meijō Park * 2006 - Meijō Park * 2005 - Meijō Park
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://nagoyawalkathon.com/?lang=en Homepage of the Nagoya Walkathon]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Clickteam SARL | logo = Click-team-company-logo.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Software industry]] | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1993}} | founders = {{Unbulleted list|[[François Lionet]]|[[Yves Lamoureux]]|[[Francis Poulain]]}} | hq_location_city = [[Boulogne-Billancourt]] | hq_location_country = France | key_people = Yves Lamoureux | products = [[Clickteam Fusion]] | website = {{URL|https://www.clickteam.com/|clickteam.com}} }} '''Clickteam SARL''' is a French [[software development]] company based in [[Boulogne-Billancourt]]. Founded in 1993 by [[François Lionet]], [[Yves Lamoureux]] and [[Francis Poulain]], Clickteam is best known for the creation of [[Clickteam Fusion]], a [[Scripting language|script]]-free [[programming tool]] that allows users to create [[video game]]s or other interactive software using a range of [[graphical user interface]] tools.
== History == Before co-founding Clickteam, [[François Lionet]] was the programmer of [[STOS BASIC]], a [[programming language]] released in 1988 for the [[Atari ST]], and [[AMOS (programming language)|AMOS BASIC]], a more advanced [[programming language]] released in 1990 for the [[Commodore International|Commodore]] [[Amiga]]. Both of these have since been released in [[open-source]] form on the Clickteam corporate website.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071130053321/http://clickteam.com/eng/downloadcenter.php?i=58 Amos & Stos » Main Download] on clickteam.com (archived 2007)</ref> [[Yves Lamoureux]] was also a successful game developer prior to co-founding Clickteam, working with multiple companies on games.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Clickteam|url=http://www.clickteam.com/about-clickteam|work=The Company and The Products|publisher=Copyright © Clickteam 2012 All Rights Reserved|accessdate=February 18, 2013}}</ref>
Clickteam's debut software was ''Klik & Play'', released in 1994 as [[Commercial software|commercial]], [[proprietary software]];<ref>{{cite book|title=The Complete Sourcebook on Children's Software|publisher=Children's Software Revue, 2001|isbn=978-1-891983-05-4 |page=608 |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=t49JTZCGBMGs8Aa_97meDg&ct=result&id=2BGxLDlrhp0C&dq=The+Complete+Sourcebook+on+Children%27s+Software&q=Klik+and+Play |author=Warren Buckleitner |accessdate=2 February 2011 |quote=Klik & Play ✓ Runs on Windows (disk or CD-ROM) 4.5****1/2 Maxis (Electronic Arts), 800-336-2947, www.maxis.com 1994, $54.95, ages 14-up ✓ Teaches creativity, logic Provides a set of 1000 animated objects...}}</ref> this marked the team's first successful software release. A version for educational use, dubbed ''Klik & Play For Schools'', was also released as [[freeware]], to be used exclusively for school activities.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Clickteam -- Creative Tools |url=http://www.clickteam.com/English/download.php |date=2001-10-05 |access-date=2016-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011005162620/http://www.clickteam.com/English/download.php |archivedate=October 5, 2001}}</ref> ''Klik & Play For Schools'' was available for download in Clickteam's website during the course of 2006, now being available for the public in general. Subsequent releases included, released in 1996, Clickteam's second product, ''Click and Create'' later renamed ''Multimedia Fusion Express'' which included more advanced features which the original ''Klik & Play'' lacked, such as scrolling, and a timeline editor, 3D game-making tool ''Jamagic''; ''The Games Factory''; ''The Games Factory 2''; and ''Multimedia Fusion''.
Clickteam's most recent application is ''Clickteam Fusion 2.5 (CF 2.5)''. This title is the successor to ''Multimedia Fusion 2'', the company's most well-received software application to date.
In September 2016 Clickteam partnered with the [[Humble Bundle]] and offered a ''Fusion 2.5'' centered bundle. Around ten games and Fusion 2.5 with various export modules were offered in the ''"Clickteam Fusion 2.5 Bundle"''. Notably, for several games the [[source code]] was included.<ref>[https://www.vgfusion.com/74-click-clickteam-boom-humble-clickteam-fusion-bundle/ Click, Clickteam, Boom! – The Humble Clickteam Fusion 2.5 Bundle] on vgfusion.com by Matt (27 September 2016)</ref><ref>[https://www.humblebundle.com/clickteam-fusion-bundle clickteam-fusion-bundle] on humblebundle.com</ref>
Fusion 3.0 was slated to be released in 2017 but as of 4th quarter 2018 the software release date has yet to be announced.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://clickfusion.academy/clickteam-fusion-3-release-date/|title=Clickteam Fusion 3 Release Date - ClickFusion Academy|date=2017-07-16|work=ClickFusion Academy|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Products == The Fusion series was designed to be a [[user-friendly]] yet powerful drag-and-drop game and application creation program, easily accessible to either those well-versed or inexperienced in programming.<ref>{{cite book|title=Game Engine Design and Implementation|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2010|isbn=978-0-7637-8451-5 |author=Alan Thorn|edition=Revised|page=26|quote=Multimedia Fusion is a commercial, proprietary game engine designed and licensed by Clickteam for the creation of 2D games for Windows}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Awesome 3D game development: no programming required|publisher=Cengage Learning, 2004|isbn=978-1-58450-325-5 |author=Clayton E. Crooks|edition=illustrated|page=72|quote=Multimedia Fusion [...is a] development tool[...] mostly used for 2D games.}}</ref>
=== Software and video game development software === * ''Klik & Play (KnP)'' - Originally created by Europress Software (Francois Lionet/Yves Lamoureux 1994) * ''Click and Create (CnC)'' - Later renamed Multimedia Fusion Express. * ''The Games Factory (TGF)'' * ''The Games Factory 2 (TGF2)'' * ''Multimedia Fusion (MMF)'' * ''Multimedia Fusion 2 (MMF2)'' * ''Clickteam Fusion 2.5 (CF2.5)'' *Clickteam Fusion 3.0 (release date TBA)
Runtime export modules for Clickteam Fusion 2.5 are available for [[Adobe Flash|Shockwave Flash]], [[iOS]], [[Microsoft XNA|XNA]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[HTML5]], [[Universal Windows Platform|UWP]] and for [[MacOS]].
=== Other products === * ''Install Creator'' (previously Install Maker) * ''Patch Maker'' * ''SynchronX'' * ''Jamagic''
== Clickteam Engine games == The most notable games made using Clickteam Engines are those in the ''[[Five Nights at Freddy's]]'' series, as well as the 2014 [[Independent game developer|indie game]] ''[[Freedom Planet]]''.
''[[I Wanna Be the Guy]]'' was made in Multimedia Fusion 2.<ref>https://kayin.moe/iwbtg/faq.php</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Crocadoo | image = File:Crocadootitle.png | caption = title screen | show_name_2 = | genre = | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = [[Tony Barry]]

David Cotter | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = [[Clive Harrison]] | country = [[Australia]] | language = English | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 52 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = Gerry Travers
John Travers | producer = Katie Cordes | editor = Djordje Lukic | location = Artarmon, Australia | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 24 minutes | company = Energee Entertainment (Sydney, Australia) | distributor = Ravensburger (Germany) | channel = [[Nine Network]] | picture_format = PAL | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 31 May 1996 | last_aired = 1998 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''Crocadoo''' is an [[Australia]]n animated series produced by [[Energee Entertainment]] and the [[Nine Network]] from 1996 to 1998. It follows the adventures of a group of blue crocodiles trying to protect their riverbank from a mad developer. CROCADOO was Energee Entertainment's first original series, its first season being digitally colored and composited with Apple computers running Adobe, Linker Systems and COSA software. First season's 3D backgrounds (Hotel, hotel interiors) were created using SGI Power Animator. Halfway through the first series, beginning with "Watch out for the Wonglebacks", some character animation was outsourced to Vietnam. CROCADOO's second season utilized Energee Entertainment's own CECAPS computer paint software. [http://www.awn.com/animationworld/crocadoo-entertains-energee] ==Characters== * '''Jazz''': A skinny, young male croc who has all the plans and ideas to encourage all the other croc's to do as he gives away plans. Voiced in the first season by [[Simon Westaway]] and in the second season by [[Hugo Weaving]] * '''Brian''': A muscled-up, young male croc who is easily gets confused, but nice and friendly. Voiced by Dave Gibson. * '''Melba''': A female croc who wears glasses, red necklace and orange dress. She is the babysitter of the baby crocs and often tries to put all the crocs on track. Voiced by [[Judy Morris]]. * '''Gina''': A blue, red haired, female croc that Brain thinks she loves him. Voiced by Maryanne Fahey * '''Waldo''': A big fat croc who loves to eat everything. Voiced in the first season by [[Simon Westaway]] and in the second season by [[Hugo Weaving]] * '''Ol' Vern''': An elderly croc the oldest of the crocs as you know. He is a storyteller and the keeper of Crocadoo. Voiced by Dave Gibson. * '''Billy''': An aboriginal teenage boy who loves playing reckless with his vehicles. Voiced by [[Aaron Pedersen]] * '''Kelly''': A teenage girl that wears green glasses who has a big brain. She is also the niece of Hardacre, but they both hate each other. Voiced by Maryanne Fahey * '''Rufus B. Hardacre''': A Hotel manager who hates crocodiles and plans to get rid of them to pave way for his new hotel development. He even hates his tourists and only cares about his money to be super rich. The antagonist of the show. Voiced by [[Tony Barry]]. * '''Ajax''': A [[Cockatoo]] who is Hardacre's sidekick and dislikes him, and will tease and belittle Hardacre any way he can. Voiced by Dave Gibson. [http://pcontent.vuclip.com:8099/partner/family_video/content/Metadata/Crocadoo%20I/Supportmaterial%20englisch/Sonstiges/Characters.pdf] ==Episodes== === Season 1: 1996 === # The Noise Machine # Watch out for the Wonglebacks # Daycare Nightmare # The Club # Almost A Ghost # Jobs For The Crocs # Jailhouse Croc # Rumble In The Jungle # Crocadoo Breakout # The Frame Up # Gone Troppo # Big Fish Blues # The Big Dry # Frankencroc # The Tourist Trap # X Is For Explorers # Urban Crocodile # Slippery Dip # Making Movies # Red Eyed Rogue # Hiccups # Cane Toad Chaos # Mixed Up Love # Tyrannosaurus Wrecks # Croc Haven # Crocs In Peril === Season 2: 1998 === # Friday The 13th # The Big Dig # Robocroc # Wipeout # White Christmas # I Scream Of Genie # Baby On Board # Trouble Ahead # Space Dog # A Bunyip Story # Pick-a-Silly-Circus # Robbing Hood # Crocodile Magic # Tree Lurking Crocs # Birthday Surprise # Holiday Hazards # Waldo The Wondercroc # Easter Feast # What’s The Time Mr. Croc? # Tiny Bit Of Trouble # Croc Olympics # Pollution In Paradise # Lost Island # Venus Croctrap # Arty Party # The Year Of The Croc == See also == * [[List of Australian television series]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Australian children's animated television series]] [[Category:Nine Network shows]] [[Category:1996 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:1998 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:1990s Australian animated television series]] {{television-stub}}

{{for|the Scotland rugby league international|Danny Arnold (rugby league)}} {{Infobox person | name = Danny Arnold | image = Danny-Arnold.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Arnold Rothmann | birth_date = {{birth date|1925|01|23}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1995|08|19|1925|01|23}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], California, U.S. | resting_place = [[Mount Sinai Memorial Park Cemetery]] | residence = Los Angeles, California | nationality = American | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Producer, screenwriter, director, actor | years_active = | known_for = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Joanne Gilbert]]|1955|1956}}
{{marriage|Donna Arnold|1961|1995}} | partner = | children = 2 | parents = | relatives = | awards = | website = }} '''Danny Arnold''' (January 23, 1925 – August 19, 1995) was an American [[television producer|producer]], [[screenwriter|writer]], [[comedian]], [[actor]] and [[television director|director]] known for producing ''[[Barney Miller]]'', ''[[That Girl]]'' and ''[[Bewitched]]''. ==Early life== Born '''Arnold Rothmann'''{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/53/Danny-Arnold.html|title=Danny Arnold Biography (1925-1995)|publisher=filmreference.com|accessdate=2012-11-23}} in [[New York City]], he started his career acting in [[summer stock]] and doing comedy in [[vaudeville]]. During [[World War II]], he served in the [[United States Marine Corps]] in the [[Pacific Ocean|South Pacific]]. He later moved to [[Hollywood]] to continue a career in show business.{{cite news | title = Danny Arnold, 70, Creator of 'Barney Miller' | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/22/obituaries/danny-arnold-70-creator-of-barney-miller.htm | date=August 22, 1995 | work= [[The New York Times]] | accessdate=2012-11-23}} ==Career== Arnold appeared in films as an actor opposite the comic duo [[Martin and Lewis]], and also wrote the screenplay for the Martin and Lewis vehicle ''[[The Caddy]]'' (1953). In 1956, Arnold started writing for such television series as ''[[The Tennessee Ernie Ford Show]]'' and ''The Rosemary Clooney Show''. In the 1960s, he began writing and producing episodes for such sitcoms as ''[[The Real McCoys]],'' ''[[Bewitched]]'', and ''[[That Girl]].'' Regarding ''Bewitched'', which he produced for its first season, Arnold noted, "With this show, I saw a great opportunity to accomplish something. Fantasy can always be a jumping-off place for more sophisticated work."{{cite news | url = http://www.harpiesbizarre.com/vintage-witch2watch.htm | title = TV's Witch to Watch | work = [[Pageant (magazine)|Pageant]] | date = April 1965}} Though his subsequent work was popular with audiences, Arnold frequently butted heads with TV executives regarding issues of content and fair shooting schedules. Television sitcom writer-director [[Ken Levine (TV writer-director)|Ken Levine]] described Arnold as "brilliant, unpredictable (a nice term for bi-polar), demanding, and kind."{{cite web | url = http://kenlevine.blogspot.com/2009/04/writing-for-barney-miller.html | date = April 13, 2009 | title = Writing for Barney Miller | publisher = [[Ken Levine (TV writer-director)|Ken Levine]] official blog | accessdate = 2013-09-05}} Tapings on ''Barney Miller'' became legendary for lasting into the wee hours as Arnold worked on rewrites;{{cite web | url = http://www.oldtvtickets.com/2010/04/barney-miller/ | authorlink = Mark Evanier | first= Mark | last= Evanier | title = Barney Miller | date = April 25, 2010 | accessdate= 2013-09-05 | publisher = OldTVTickets.com}} due to these extended tapings the show in its later seasons ceased having a live audience.{{cite web | url = http://zvbxrpl.blogspot.com/2006/03/bewitched-year-of-danny-arnold.html |title = "Bewitched": The Year of Danny Arnold | date= March 26, 2006 | publisher= Something Old, Something New (blog of ''[[Maclean's]]'' assistant editor) | first= Jaime J. | last= Weinman}} While working on ''[[Barney Miller]]'', Arnold became so sick of the constant network battles that he founded his own distribution company '''Pro-Synd, Inc.''', so he could syndicate shows as he wished, but with the cancellation of his subsequent series ''[[Joe Bash]]'' and ''Stat'', his plans for ''Barney Miller'' never came to fruition. He eventually sued regarding what he felt was the unfair sharing of the profits from ''Barney Miller'' and got a $50 million settlement.{{cite news | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,314221,00.html | title = Stat Man Danny Arnold | work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | date = May 3, 1991 | first= Mark | last = Harris}} On August 28, 1986, Danny Arnold sold his production company '''Four D Productions, Inc.''' to [[Coca-Cola]]'s [[Columbia Pictures Television]] Group for $50 million after Arnold dropped the federal and state lawsuits against Columbia Pictures Industries accusing them of [[antitrust]] violations, [[fraud]], and breach of [[fiduciary duty]].{{cite news|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1986/Coke-to-Buy-Film-Concern-to-Settle-Suits/id-50b6146fe983b49d631795746d0bd2dc |title=Coke to Buy Film Concern to Settle Suits |date=August 29, 1986 |publisher=[[AP News Archive]] |accessdate=2013-11-30 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LWRB1H3w?url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1986/Coke-to-Buy-Film-Concern-to-Settle-Suits/id-50b6146fe983b49d631795746d0bd2dc |archivedate=November 30, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} Arnold won two [[Emmy Award]]s, one for ''[[My World and Welcome to It]]'' and one for the series for which he is most famous, ''[[Barney Miller]]''. This latter show also won Arnold a [[Peabody Award]]. He was honored with the [[Paddy Chayefsky]] [[Award]] in 1985 by the [[Writers Guild of America, West|Writer's Guild of America]] to celebrate his lifetime of achievement. ===Filmography=== * ''[[Barney Miller]]'' (1975–1982, produced by Four D Productions) * ''[[Fish (U.S. TV series)|Fish]]'' (1977–1978, produced by the Mimus Corporation) * ''[[A.E.S. Hudson Street]]'' (1978, produced by the Triseme Corporation) * ''[[Joe Bash]]'' (1986, produced by Tetagram Ltd.) * ''Stat'' (1986) ==Personal life== Arnold was married twice and had two children. His first marriage was to the daughter of songwriter [[Ray Gilbert]], actress [[Joanne Gilbert]], in 1955.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4lEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=21AEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3466,3760897&dq=danny+arnold+joanne+gilbert&hl=en|title=Behind the Scenes In Hollywood|last=Carroll|first=Harrison|date=1955-01-04|work=The Dispatch|page=5|accessdate=2012-11-23}} The marriage ended the following year.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SQ5WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=c-IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6854,2827847&dq=danny+arnold+joanne+gilbert&hl=en|title=Files for Divorce|date=June 17, 1956 |work=[[The Register-Guard]] | location = [[Eugene, Oregon]] | page=12C|accessdate=2012-11-23}} Arnold met his second wife, Donna, while he was working as a writer on ''The Tennessee Ernie Ford Show'' and she was appearing as a singer and dancer on the program.{{cite web|url=http://cs.bloodhorse.com/blogs/winners-circle/archive/2011/09/27/hoping-for-an-encore-donna-arnold-by-david-schmitz.aspx|title=Hoping for an Encore: Donna Arnold|last=Schmitz|first=David|date=September 27, 2011|publisher=bloodhorse.com|accessdate=2012-11-23}} They married in 1961 and had two children, David and Dannel. The couple remained married until Arnold's death. ==Death== On August 19, 1995, Arnold died of [[heart failure]] at his Los Angeles home at the age of 70.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Df8cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z44EAAAAIBAJ&pg=1658,1020712&dq=danny+arnold+heart+failure&hl=en|title=Danny Arnold, Television Producer|date=August 8, 1995 | work = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] | location = [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] | accessdate=2012-11-23}} He is buried at [[Mount Sinai Memorial Park Cemetery]] in Los Angeles. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} *{{IMDb name|0036400}} *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/guide/talent/a/arnold_danny.shtml Danny Arnold] at the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] *[http://www.bobclaster.com Half-hour KCRW interview "Bob Claster's Funny Stuff"] *{{YouTube|GGDDXuVEdr8|Arnold uncredited cameo on ''That Girl''}} *{{Find a Grave|9027}} {{Authority control}} [[Alan Zweibel]] |basis = |productions = 1984 [[Off Broadway]] |awards = }} '''''Diamonds''''' is a [[musical theatre|musical]] [[revue]] about baseball. The book and music were created by many writers, composers, and lyricists. Among them were Ellen Fitzhugh, [[Roy Blount, Jr.]], and [[John Weidman]] (book); and Larry Grossman, [[Comden and Green]], [[Howard Ashman]], and [[Cy Coleman]], music.Suskin, Steven. "Cy Coleman", ''Show Tunes: The Songs, Shows, and Careers of Broadway's Major Composers'', Oxford University Press, 2000, {{ISBN|0195125991}}, p. 319 The musical ran [[Off Broadway]] at the [[Circle in the Square Theatre|Circle in the Square]] Downtown theater, beginning on December 16, 1984 and closing on March 31, 1985, after 122 performances. The production was directed by [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] veteran [[Harold Prince]]. The cast included [[Loni Ackerman]], Susan Bigelow, [[Jackée Harry]], Scott Holmes, [[Dick Latessa]], Dwayne Markee, Wade Raley, Larry Riley, [[Nestor Serrano]], [[Gordon Stanley]] and [[Chip Zien]]. The musical won the [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] for Best Set Design, by Tony Straiges. ==Songs== * Winter In New York (music: [[John Kander]], lyrics: [[Fred Ebb]]) * In The Cards (music: [[Alan Menken]], lyrics: [[David Zippel]]) * Favorite Sons (music: [[Larry Grossman (composer)|Larry Grossman]], lyrics: Ellen Fitzhugh) * Song for a Pinch Hitter (music: Larry Grossman, lyrics: Ellen Fitzhugh) * Vendors (music: [[Cy Coleman]], lyrics: [[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]]) * What You'd Call a Dream (music and lyrics: [[Craig Carnelia]]) * Escorte-Moi (music and lyrics: [[Albert Von Tilzer]] and [[Jack Norworth]]) * He Threw Out The Ball (music: [[Larry Grossman (composer)|Larry Grossman]], lyrics: Ellen Fitzhugh) * Hundreds of Hats (music: Jonathan Sheffer, lyrics: [[Howard Ashman]]) * 1919 (music and lyrics: Jim Wann) * Let's Play Ball (music and lyrics: [[Gerard Alessandrini]]) * Vendors #2 (music: [[Cy Coleman]], lyrics: [[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]]) * The Boys of Summer (music: [[Larry Grossman (composer)|Larry Grossman]], lyrics: Ellen Fitzhugh) * Song for a Hunter College Graduate (music: Jonathan Sheffer, lyrics: [[Howard Ashman]]) * Stay in Your Own Back Yard (music: Lyn Udall, lyrics: Karl Kennett, additional music: Pam Drews) * Ka-Razy (music: [[Doug Katsaros]], lyrics: [[David Zippel]]) * Diamonds Are Forever (music: [[John Kander]], lyrics: [[Fred Ebb]]) ==Critical response== The ''Los Angeles Times'' quoted several reviews of the piece. "Is it a hit ? Will it have a run ? [[Frank Rich]] of the ''New York Times'' didn't particularly think so. [[Clive Barnes]] of the ''New York Post'' definitely thought not: 'A fiasco of the smallest, dullest kind. Say it ain't so, Hal.' But the ''Daily News'' Doug Watt thought the show had some cute ideas, such as its Kabuki-style rendering of 'Casey at the Bat.' His final verdict: 'Call 'Diamonds' a Little League homer and let it go at that.'"Sullivan, Dan. [http://articles.latimes.com/1985-01-05/entertainment/ca-11662_1_firepower "Glenda Jackson Shows Firepower In 'Phedre'"], ''Los Angeles Times'', January 5, 1985 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&title=Diamonds Internet Off-Broadway Database listing] [[Category:1984 musicals]] [[Category:Off-Broadway musicals]] [[Category:Revues]] {{musical-theat-stub}}

[[File:Forrest J. Ackerman, collector of movie memorabilia, with fan..jpg|thumb|200px|Collector [[Forrest J. Ackerman]] lets a fan pose in a cape worn by [[Bela Lugosi]] in footage used by director [[Ed Wood]] in ''[[Plan 9 From Outer Space]]'']] '''Film memorabilia''' are objects considered of value because of their connection to the cinema. These include costumes, [[Theatrical property|props]], [[Film poster|advertising posters]], and [[Screenplay|script]]s, among other things. Fans have always coveted memorabilia, but in recent years, what was once a hobby has mushroomed into big business, with millions of dollars changing hands in auctions held by such top firms as [[Christie's]] and [[Sotheby's]]. In addition, many popular films have their collectible items sold via independent, online movie memorabilia stores, web auctions, and at film studio charity events.<ref name="Mohr">Ian Mohr ''Daily Variety''. Reed Business Information February 27, 2006 [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117938954.html?categoryid=1238&cs=1 "Movie props on the block: Mouse to auction Miramax leftovers"]</ref><ref name="James">David James ''People Magazine'' Time Inc. February 24, 2007 [http://offtherack.people.com/2007/02/dress_like_a_dr.html#comment-66215834 "Bid on Dreamgirls Costumes for Charity"]</ref>
==History of collecting== In the early days, most people sought autographs or original photographs or posters. Collectors had to rely on a handful of news magazines that were full of various sellers offering mail order catalogues or asking to buy bulk lots, or particular items of interest. Occasionally, events would be organized which were structured around a live auction — these, while fewer in number today, still occur, and one can still buy memorabilia in person from trusted sellers on-site. The community was also fairly fragmented, with collectors and dealers spread out across the globe and no real consistent and reliable way to communicate with one another.
Movie studios were slow to recognize the value of their property,<ref name=NYT>{{cite news |title=Once Movie Trash, Now Collectible |author=Larry Rohter |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=May 26, 1990 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/26/movies/once-movie-trash-now-collectible.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref> "generally viewing the material as junk taking up precious backlot real estate."<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/seedy-underworld-movie-memorabilia-1117268 |title=A Marvel Heist and the Booming Business (and Seedy Underworld) of Movie Collectibles |author=Gary Baum |date=June 8, 2018 |magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref> Often, workers would just take souvenirs or sell items without permission, aware that their employers did not particularly care.<ref name=NYT/> One of the more notorious of these was costumer [[Kent Warner]], who amassed a large private collection and made money selling to interested buyers. One of his friends claimed that Warner rescued [[Humphrey Bogart]]'s ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'' [[trench coat]], which had been slated for burning.<ref name=LATimes>{{cite news |title=The Ruby Slippers: A Journey to the Land of Oz |author=Rhys Thomas |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=March 13, 1988 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-03-13/entertainment/ca-1511_1_ruby-slipper}}</ref>
The turning point came in 1970. [[Kirk Kerkorian]] had bought [[MGM]] the year before and installed [[James Thomas Aubrey, Jr.]] as president.<ref name=NYT_obit>{{cite news |title=James Aubrey Jr., 75, TV and Film Executive |author=Eric Pace |newspaper=New York Times |date=September 12, 1994 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/12/obituaries/james-aubrey-jr-75-tv-and-film-executive.html?pagewanted=1}}</ref> As part of his cost-cutting measures,<ref name=NYT_obit/> Aubrey decided to auction off hundreds of thousands of items. The success of this mammoth event made people take notice.
===1970 MGM auction=== MGM sold the contents of seven sound stages<ref name=Julien/> "for a mere $1.5 million" to auctioneer David Weisz.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news |title=MGM bankruptcy: lion's roar has long been a whimper |author=David Gritten |newspaper=[[Telegraph.co.uk]] |date=April 22, 2010 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/7618260/MGM-bankruptcy-lions-roar-has-long-been-a-whimper.html}}</ref> There were over 350,000 costumes alone.<ref name=Julien>{{cite web |url=http://www.juliensauctions.com/collectors-guide/entertainment-memorabilia.html |title=Collecting Entertainment Memorabilia |publisher=[[Julien's Auctions]] |accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref> Weisz hired Kent Warner to help catalog and prepare for the auction.<ref name=LATimes/> In the course of his work, Warner found several pairs of the [[ruby slippers]] from ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (it is common practice to make multiple copies of important props). One pair became the centerpiece of the event and sold for a then-unheard-of $15,000 (Warner kept or sold an unknown number of other pairs).
Actress [[Debbie Reynolds]] spent $180,000<ref name="LATimes"/> and "purchased thousands of items",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.debbiereynolds.com/debbie-reynolds-biography.htm |title=Biography |publisher=debbiereynolds.com |accessdate=April 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803133908/http://www.debbiereynolds.com/debbie-reynolds-biography.htm |archivedate=August 3, 2009 |df= }}</ref> the beginning of her large collection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kcts9.org/programs/productions/conversations/transcript/dreynolds |title=Interview with Debbie Reynolds |publisher=[[KCTS-TV|KCTS-9]] |accessdate=April 28, 2010}}</ref> Weisz "recouped eight times" what he paid "from eager nostalgia enthusiasts."<ref name=Telegraph/>
Among the items sold were: *the [[Cowardly Lion#Cowardly Lion costumes|Cowardly Lion costume]] from ''The Wizard of Oz'' *the time machine from the 1960 film ''[[The Time Machine (1960 film)|The Time Machine]]'' *the 82 inch<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liveauctioneers.com/item/5966041 |title=Orig flying saucer miniature from Forbidden Planet |publisher=liveauctioneers.com |accessdate=April 28, 2010}}</ref> and 22 inch<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monsters411.com/wesshank.html |title=Wes Shank Interview |publisher=monsters411.com |author=[[Ted A. Bohus]] |accessdate=April 28, 2010}}</ref> (diameter) models of the "United Planets Cruiser C-57D" from ''[[Forbidden Planet]]'' *[[Johnny Weissmuller]]'s Tarzan loincloth<ref name=Julien/>
The unsold items, "... truckloads of costume sketches, movie stills and other memorabilia were sent to the [[Bally's Las Vegas|MGM Grand Hotel]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] to be sold in the gift shop and used as hotel decorations."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/24/movies/film-history-being-lost-by-oversight-and-plan.html?pagewanted=1 |title=FILM HISTORY BEING LOST BY OVERSIGHT AND PLAN |author=[[Aljean Harmetz]] |newspaper=New York Times |date=March 24, 1987}}</ref> The auction catalogs have now themselves become sought-after collectibles.
===2011 Debbie Reynolds auctions=== Debbie Reynolds' collection was sold by Profiles in History in two auctions in June and December 2011.<ref name=Sun>{{cite news |title=Marilyn Monroe's skirt going up - on auction block |author=Jay Stone |newspaper=Vancouver Sun |date=February 27, 2011 |url=https://vancouversun.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Marilyn+Monroe+skirt+going+auction+block/4352729/story.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609215004/http://www.vancouversun.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Marilyn+Monroe+skirt+going+auction+block/4352729/story.html |archivedate=June 9, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Among the items to be put up for bid in the first of these auctions are:<ref name=Sun/> *[[Marilyn Monroe]]'s "[[White dress of Marilyn Monroe|subway dress]]", whose skirt is raised by the updraft of a passing subway train in ''[[The Seven Year Itch]]''. *one of [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s trademark [[bowler hat]]s *an early, unused Arabian motif version of the ruby slippers from ''The Wizard of Oz'' *[[Audrey Hepburn]]'s Ascot dress and hat from ''[[My Fair Lady]]'' *[[Charlton Heston]]'s tunic, robe, and accessories from ''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]''
On June 18, 2011, the subway dress sold for $4.6 million, far in excess of pre-auction estimates of $1–2 million.<ref name=Reuters>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/19/us-monroe-idUSTRE75I2NM20110619 |title=Marilyn Monroe "subway" dress sells for $4.6 million |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=June 19, 2011 |accessdate=June 19, 2011}}</ref> Another Monroe dress, worn in ''[[Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (1953 film)|Gentlemen Prefer Blondes]]'', fetched $1.2 million; it had been expected to go for $200,000 to $300,000.<ref name=Reuters/> Estimated at $60,000 to $80,000, a blue cotton dress [[Judy Garland]] used in test shots for ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' went for $910,000.<ref name=Reuters/> In total, the auction grossed $22.8 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-24/hollywood-auction-ends-myth-of-zaftig-marilyn-virginia-postrel.html |title=Hollywood Auction Ends Myth of Zaftig Marilyn |author=[[Virginia Postrel]] |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=June 23, 2011 |accessdate=March 17, 2012}}</ref>
In the second Reynolds auction, on December 3, 2011, a still-functioning Panavision PSR 35mm camera used to film ''[[Star Wars]]'' went for $625,000, breaking records for ''Star Wars'' memorabilia and vintage cameras.<ref>{{cite news |title=Star Wars camera breaks auction record |author=Ben Child |newspaper=[[guardian.co.uk]] |date=6 December 2011 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/dec/06/star-wars-camera-auction-record}}</ref>
==Influence of the internet== In the early days of the internet, the larger community began to get in touch with one another through [[UseNet]] [[newsgroups]] (for example, alt.binaries.pictures.movie-posters). As the internet grew, collectors began communicating in ways never thought possible. In 1995, popular on-line email group [http://www.filmfan.com MoPo] was formed, creating a central place for people to keep in touch about things and events important to the community. This group continues to provide information to new and old collectors alike.
By 1997, the community had changed forever; [[eBay]] was quickly becoming the alternative marketplace after two years of steady growth. Professional sellers took notice, causing many of them to close their bricks-and-mortar businesses and focus their attention completely on internet sites and the future of the on-line marketplace.
In the early days of internet selling, prices varied widely. One could find posters normally valued in the hundreds of dollars selling for twenty dollars, or, alternatively, find posters normally valued at twenty dollars going for a hundred, or more. Today, the market place for film memorabilia has mostly stabilised. While one can still see a rare film poster go for large amounts, it is far more common to find that items are priced either at or near market value, or are bid up to that point.
==Types== *Film posters *Lobby cards *Still photos *Autographs *Film props *Costumes *Pressbooks and presskits *Programmes *Heralds *Glass slides *Industry magazines and related material *Scripts, storyboards, and original concept art *Promotional material of any kind *Commercial collectibles
==Notable examples== {{Main|List of film memorabilia}} *Several pairs of the ruby slippers from ''The Wizard of Oz'' are known to exist. One pair is on permanent display at the [[National Museum of American History]], several others are in the hands of private collectors, and one pair was stolen in 2005. The last auction price, in 2000, was $666,000. Also, the black hat belonging to the Wicked Witch of the West sold for $33,000 in 1988<ref name=LATimes/> and $197,400 in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/12/03/wizard-slippers-collection-forbeslife-cx_mb_1203slippers.html |title=Inside The Search For Dorothy's Slippers |author=Monte Burke |publisher=''[[Forbes]]'' |date=December 3, 2008 |accessdate=April 28, 2010}}</ref> *[[Image:Conrad-Maltese-Falcon.jpg|thumb|The William Conrad ''Maltese Falcon'' statuette]]There were several statuettes made for the 1941 ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1941 film)|The Maltese Falcon]]'' — two lead figures weighing {{convert|47|lb|kg}} each, and a seven-pound (3.2 kg), more finely crafted, resin model — all handled by [[Humphrey Bogart]]. Christie's auctioned one of the lead figures, part of the estate of actor [[William Conrad]], on December 6, 1994; it was purchased for $398,500 by Ronald Winston, president of [[Harry Winston, Inc.]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Maltese Falcon Prop Sells For $398,500 At Auction |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=December 7, 1994 |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-12-07/news/9412070081_1_maltese-falcon-ronald-winston-harry-winston-jewelry}}</ref> Within two years, Winston had resold the prop "at an enormous profit" — for as much as $1 million — to an unknown European collector.<ref>{{cite news |last=LeDuff |first=Charles |date=June 29, 1997 |title=Bird Made Him a Sleuth |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/29/nyregion/bird-made-him-a-sleuth.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref> On November 25, 2013, [[Bonhams]], in association with [[Turner Classic Movies|TCM]], sold the other lead figure, the only one confirmed to have appeared in the movie, for over $4 million, including the buyers fee.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writers; no by-line.--> |title=Maltese Falcon prop stars at auction |url=http://www.euronews.com/2013/11/27/maltese-falcon-prop-stars-at-auction/ |publisher=euronews.com |date=Nov 27, 2013 |accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref> This version has a prop number WB 90067.<ref>Bonhams, [http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/21427/lot/225/ Lot No. 225], online catalog for "What Dreams are Made Of", November 25, 2013</ref> (See also ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1941 film)#Falcon props|The Maltese Falcon]]''.) *On November 24, 2014, the piano on which Sam plays "As Time Goes By" in Rick's Café Américain (and in which Rick hides the letters of transit) was sold for $2,900,000 (the buyer's premium bringing the total to $3,413,000) by [[Bonhams]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/22196/lot/83/ |title=The Piano From Casablanca On Which Sam Plays "As Time Goes By" |publisher=[[Bonhams]] |accessdate=November 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=‘Casablanca’ Piano Sells for $3.4 Million at Bonhams |author=James Barron |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 24, 2014 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/25/nyregion/casablanca-piano-to-be-auctioned-at-bonhams.html?_r=0}}</ref> In the same auction, the only known surviving copy of the transit papers, though apparently not used onscreen,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/22196/lot/84/ |title=The Production-Made "Transit Papers" From Casablanca |publisher=Bonhams |accessdate=November 24, 2014}}</ref> went for $118,750 (including buyer's premium). *[[Audrey Hepburn]] was not only a celebrated actress, but also a fashion icon. In 2006, her "[[Black Givenchy dress of Audrey Hepburn|little black dress]]" from ''[[Breakfast at Tiffany's (film)|Breakfast at Tiffany's]]'' (plus a few other minor items) fetched £467,200 ($923,187) for the City of Joy Foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=4832498 |title=Audrey Hepburn Breakfast At Tiffany's, 1961 |publisher=Christie's |accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref> *[[Steven Spielberg]] paid $60,500 (including 10% commission) in June 1982 for a "Rosebud" sled from ''[[Citizen Kane]]''. [[Orson Welles]] stated in a telephone interview that there were three made of [[balsa]] (as is Spielberg's purchase) that were intended to be burned in the final scene, and one made of hardwood for the beginning of the film. On December 15, 1996, the hardwood sled was sold to an anonymous bidder in Los Angeles for $233,500.<ref>"Clark Gable's Oscar and 'Rosebud' sled sold"; [[Associated Press]], December 15, 1996</ref> *The white suit worn by [[John Travolta]] in ''[[Saturday Night Fever]]'' was purchased by film critic [[Gene Siskel]] in a charity auction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19990307/REVIEWS08/401010357/1023 |title=Saturday Night Fever (1977) |author=Roger Ebert |publisher=rogerebert.com |date=March 7, 1999 |accessdate=April 22, 2010}}</ref> In June 1995 it was auctioned at Christie's for $145,500.<ref>[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/memorabilia/saturday-night-fever-1977-327819-details.aspx?from=searchresults&intObjectID=327819&sid=7e32b9b3-db12-42b4-9acc-17fd7b17e0c9 "Saturday Night Fever, 1977,"] sale 7741, lot 155. [[Christie's]], retrieved March 18, 2012</ref>

The '''''formes fixes''''' (singular '''''forme fixe''''', "fixed form") are the three fourteenth- and fifteenth-centuries [[French language|French]] [[poetry|poetic]] forms: the ''[[ballade (forme fixe)|ballade]], [[rondeau (poetry)|rondeau]]'' and ''[[virelai]]''. Each was also a musical form, generally a ''[[chanson]]'', and all consisted of a complex pattern of repetition of [[Verse (poetry)|verse]]s and a [[refrain]] with musical content in two main sections.
All three forms can be found in thirteenth-century sources but a fifteenth-century source gives [[Philippe de Vitry]] as their first composer while the first comprehensive repertory of these forms was written by [[Guillaume de Machaut]].<ref name="Fallows">Fallows</ref> The ''formes fixes'' stopped being used in music around the end of the fifteenth century, although their influence continued (in poetry they, especially the rondeau, continued to be used<ref name="Fallows"/>).
Sometimes forms from other countries and periods are referred to as ''formes fixes''. These include the Italian fourteenth century [[madrigal (Trecento)|madrigal]] and later [[ballata]] and [[barzelletta]], the German [[bar form]], Spanish 13th century [[cantiga]], and the later [[canción]], and [[villancico]].<ref name="Fallows"/>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
